Following the Younger Dryas, new forms of sites appear in North China, represented by Nanzhuangtou (Hebei) and Donghulin (Beijing). Such sites, likely featuring more extensive wild cereal cultivation, could belong to less mobile or semi-sedentary groups. Nanzhuangtou (39°6′40″N, 115°39′25″E; 11,500–11,200 cal BP)
5, 23 features flake tools (without microblades), polished axes, more querns and mullers, clearly defined activity areas, pottery, domesticated dogs, and wild pig and chicken. At Donghulin (39°58′48″N, 115°43′36″E) (11,150 to 9500 cal BP)
2, 23 , microblades are still present, but appear along with pit burials, pit-houses, and hearth pits.
